title: 112_s647
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Montana Mineral Conveyance Act". Congress finds that the Secretary of the Interior has conveyed mineral rights in large coal tracts near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation to the State of Montana. The development of these tracts and other energy resources in the surrounding areas generates significant public revenues for the State, aiding in addressing the impacts of development on the Northern Cheyenne tribal community. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe faces economic challenges and lacks revenue sources to address development impacts. In 2002, the Tribe sued the Secretary over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts to the State. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe withdrew a lawsuit against the Secretary over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts to the State, citing commitments for legislation to address impacts of coal development. The Tribe asserts retaining claims against the State and others. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe will introduce legislation to address coal development impacts with support from the State and others. The Tribe retains claims against the United States for failing to acquire mineral rights on Reservation land, which are now owned by Great Northern Properties. If mineral rights conveyances are carried out, the Tribe will waive legal claims against the United States for the loss of mineral rights. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe will introduce legislation to address coal development impacts with support from the State and others. They retain claims against the United States for failing to acquire mineral rights on Reservation land, now owned by Great Northern Properties. If mineral rights conveyances occur, the Tribe will waive legal claims for the loss of mineral rights. The Cheyenne tracts, totaling 5,000 acres within the Reservation boundaries, are defined by specific land sections as depicted on a map dated April 7, 2010. The Federal tracts are unleased land sections located in the State, outside Reservation boundaries. The Federal tracts are unleased land sections located in the State, outside Reservation boundaries, consisting of approximately 5,000 acres. These tracts are depicted on a specific map and are comprised of specific land locations within different sections. The Federal tracts, totaling around 5,000 acres, are located outside Reservation boundaries and consist of specific land sections in different areas, including T. 3 S., R. 45 E., sec. 30, T. 4 S., R. 44 E., sec. 2, T. 6 N., R. 27 E., sec. 4, sec. 8, sec. 10, sec. 14, and sec. 22. The term "Great Northern Properties" refers to the Great Northern Properties Limited Partnership, a Delaware limited partnership, and any successor to its ownership interest. The term "Properties" refers to the Great Northern Properties Limited Partnership, a Delaware limited partnership, and any successor to its ownership interest in coal or iron under the Cheyenne tracts. The term "Reservation" refers to the Northern Cheyenne Reservation. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "State" refers to the State of Montana. The term "Tribe" refers to the Northern Cheyenne Tribe. SEC. 4. MINERAL RIGHTS CONVEYANCES.

Great Northern Properties will convey mineral interests to the Tribe, and in return, the Secretary will convey coal rights to Great Northern Properties. The mineral interests conveyed to the Tribe will be immune from state taxation.

SEC. 5. TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF MINERAL CONVEYANCES. The Tribe will waive legal claims in exchange for mineral conveyances. The Tribe and Great Northern Properties must agree on revenue sharing for coal production. Mineral conveyances must be completed within 90 days of agreement on revenue sharing. Federal law applies to the conveyance of Federal coal rights. Mineral conveyances under section 4(a) must be completed in a single transaction. Rescission of mineral conveyances can occur if invalidated by a Federal district court. The Secretary or Great Northern Properties may rescind mineral conveyances if necessary. If the Secretary or Great Northern Properties rescind a mineral conveyance under section 4(a), the Tribe's waiver under subsection (a) will also be rescinded. SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL BENEFITS.

No benefits provided to the Tribe under this Act shall affect their eligibility for any Federal services or programs due to their status as a federally recognized Indian tribe or the status of its members.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations necessary to carry out this Act are authorized.
